steps.text: Evaluate fire risks in working machines.
Issue clear instructions for machine safety.
Supervise compliance with issued instructions.
Begin operation of the machine.
Assess fire risks based on factors such as impact on company risks, employee actions, preventive maintenance, and daily work.
Perform scheduled maintenance according to manufacturer's instructions.
Participate in manufacturer recall campaigns.
Use authentic replacement parts from known manufacturers.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings daily in dusty or fire-hazard conditions.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings weekly in other environments.
Perform cleaning after a shift.
Use compressed air to remove dirt.
Inspect for leaks after cleaning.
Check joints of hoses and pipes.
Inspect engine compartment for oil leaks.
Protect hoses from heat with thermal shields or tubes.
Repair any leaks immediately.
Visually inspect electrical systems at least once a year.
Document inspections.
Service electrical systems daily on electric-powered and hybrid machines.
Use a multimeter to measure voltage drops.
A drop exceeding 20W indicates an increased fire risk.
Inspect electrical systems with a thermal imaging camera.
Compare readings with an intact machine.
Locate and check the main power switch.
Ensure the switch is outside the engine compartment and visibly marked.
Check switch poles have terminal covers.
Verify power is cut off when the switch is used.
Locate and operate the emergency kill switch.
Repair any malfunctions before resuming operation.
Check battery condition.
Check cables for damage and protect unprotected ones.
Replace damaged cables.
Protect cables with a housing pipe.
Keep cables clean.
Firmly attach cable harnesses.
Ensure cable connections are tight and covered.
Check the electric panel during maintenance.
Fuse boxes must be intact and have lids. Ensure fuses are the correct size.
Investigate the cause of any blown fuse.
Attach cables in the high-vibration engine compartment.
Firmly attach alternator with correct belt tension and have terminal covers.
Keep alternator filter clean to prevent overheating.
Check for anomalies using a thermal camera.
During maintenance, check fasteners, belts, and bearings.
Replace noisy bearings.
Check exhaust pipe for leaks and ensure all thermal shields are in place.
Ensure regeneration occurs in a safe outdoor environment away from flammable materials.
Delay regeneration if the machine is in a fire-hazard environment.
Inspect all hoses and electrical systems in the swivelling joint weekly.
Remove any rocks or twigs found in the swivelling joint immediately.
Ensure all operating manuals are available in the machine and understandable by the operator.
Check the cleanliness and condition of the auxiliary heater, its compartment, and its wiring before winter.
Test the heater under supervision before use.
Machines with a weight exceeding 3,000 kg require a minimum of two hand-held fire extinguishers (34A233B) for frost-resistant liquid-based fire extinction.
Machines used for crushing timber or energy waste necessitate four hand-held fire extinguishers (34A233B) that should be accessible at ground level.
Make sure all hand-held fire extinguishers are easily accessible, clearly marked, and undergo annual servicing.
Provide training to operators on the proper usage of hand-held fire extinguishers.
Autonomous machines must have a fixed fire extinguishing system.
System protects hot components, flammable liquid hoses/tanks, and electrical components.
Machines in dust or fire hazard environments require a fully automatic system.
There must be at least 3 liters of extinguishing agent per cubic meter of engine or heater compartment.
Detection system covers entire engine compartment.
Detection system is connected to non-fused cables.
Confirm system operation at start-up.
Repair any malfunctions immediately by an authorized shop.
Service the system at least once a year.
Clean engine compartments daily.
During fire safety inspection, check for clear markings on fire extinguishing openings.
Use approved extinguishing equipment suppliers: Dafo Oy, Fogmaker, Firestop, ExAct Guard, Ceodeux Extinguisher Valves Technology S.A/Rotarex, Teknosafe Oy.
Remain calm.
Shut down the engine as quickly as possible.
If indoors, move the machine outdoors first.
If near flammable material, move the machine before shutting down.
Cut electricity from the main power switch.
Call for help (emergency number 112).
Use the 112 smartphone app if possible.
Perform first-aid fire extinguishing.
Confirm fire is out with the fire department.
Report the incident to the safety officer, site manager, coworkers, and insurance company.
Report all accidents and dangerous situations to a supervisor immediately.
Stop and leave the machine in place if possible.
Prevent further damage and minimize injuries.
Wear protective clothing and a helmet.
Use a hands-free device for phone calls.
Wear a safety belt.
Use stepladders and handrails while climbing, maintaining three points of contact.
Keep doors closed during operation.
Ensure tools are secure.
Repair any malfunctions that could lead to an accident without delay.
Arrange practical training on accident and fire procedures.
Check items such as cables and fasteners for security, heat resistance, insulation, lead-throughs.
Examine fuses and batteries for condition of non-fused cables and terminal covers.
Inspect engine and heater compartments for cleanliness and leaks.
Verify first-aid extinguishing equipment availability, markings, and operator training.

constraints.text: Working machines over 500 kg must have a main power switch located outside the engine compartment and visibly marked.
Switch poles must have terminal covers.
Power should be cut off when the switch is used.
Repair any deviations before operating the machine.
Cable terminals must be intact, firmly attached, and protected with terminal covers to prevent overheating.
The battery compartment needs sufficient ventilation.
Fuse boxes must be intact and have lids. Ensure fuses are the correct size.
Cables in the high-vibration engine compartment must have fastening brackets no more than 150 mm apart.
Fasteners and cable ties should withstand temperatures of 120°C.
Do not attach cables to pipes or hoses containing flammable material.
